title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.11.13-14 | 05-07-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurunmilitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and the Lord.

segments.key_quote: the whole city is prepared to welcome the Lord
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 13th verse of the 11th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, describing the decorations and preparations made to welcome the Lord in the city, emphasizing the use of natural elements like plantain trees and mango leaves.

segments.key_quote: Whenever there is a need in the Vedic culture for decoration, they utilize such natural things.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the Vedic tradition of using natural decorations with modern artificial decorations, highlighting the environmental benefits of biodegradable natural products compared to non-biodegradable materials like plastic.

segments.key_quote: Krishna says in Bhagavatam madbhakta puja abhyadika worship of my devotee is greater than worship of me
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the significance of Hanuman and Garuda as great servitors of the Lord, emphasizing that honoring devotees pleases the Lord and highlighting the decorations of flags with their images.

segments.key_quote: Hanuman is extraordinarily powerful but he uses all that power only for service of Lord Rama not for any other purpose
segments.summary: The speaker narrates pastimes of Krishna with Garuda and Rama with Hanuman, emphasizing their selfless service and contrasting it with the misuse of power for sense gratification in the material world.

segments.key_quote: everything is used simply for devotional service of the Supreme Lord that's all that's the ideal
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the ideal of using all abilities and power for the devotional service of the Supreme Lord, citing Garuda's devotion as an example.

segments.key_quote: the highways subways lanes markets and public meeting places were all thoroughly cleansed and then moistened with scented water
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 14th verse, describing the cleanliness and opulence of Dwarka, where roads were cleansed and scented with natural flower extracts to welcome the Lord.

segments.key_quote: Cleanliness is very prominent in Vedic civilization.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of cleanliness in Vedic civilization and contrasts the former abundance of parks and gardens with the modern-day concrete jungles in cities.

segments.key_quote: When Krishna Consciousness is there, there is plenty of supply of everything by material nature.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna consciousness leads to an abundance of natural resources and describes Dwaraka as an ideal city where everyone was devoted to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: That is the ideal for human civilization.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stating that a society devoted to Krishna is the ideal for human civilization and ends with Hare Krishna.
